Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Oliver A. Pechenik is "Advances in K-Theoretic Schubert Calculus." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Michigan, and the sponsoring scientist is David Speyer.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The three years of the PI's Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Mathematics resulted in nine published research papers, four conference proceedings, and one expository book chapter in mathematics, as well as fourteen invited lectures. 

 

Intellectual Merit: In joint work with Dominic Searles, the PI gave an elementary explanation of a deformed cohomology ring due to Belkale and Kumar. We further introduced glide polynomials, with applications to K-theoretic Schubert calculus. In further work with Cara Monical, we further developed the combinatorics of K-theoretic polynomials. The PI mentored undergraduates Rahul Ilango and Michael Zlatin to introduce new combinatorics with applications to K-theoretic Schubert calculus in the Kac-Moody setting. The PI's solo paper on genomic Schur functions establishes a surprising positivity property that they enjoy.

With Zachary Hamaker, Rebecca Patrias, and Nathan Williams, the PI used the combinatorics of K-theoretic Schubert calculus to give a combinatorial proof of a mysterious 1983 equivalence of Proctor. In further work with Patrias, the PI used similar ideas to establish a 1995 conjecture of Cameron and Fon-Der-Flaass on the dynamics of plane partitions. Holly Mandel and the PI used similar ideas to resolve conjectures of Rush and Shi on plane partitions of exceptional Lie type. 

With Hamaker, David Speyer, and Anna Weigandt, the PI proved a conjecture of Richard Stanley, using combinatorics from Schubert calculus to understand the structure of certain partially-ordered sets.

Intellectual Merit: The PI mentored two undergraduates in their first research experience, producing the paper mentioned above. The PI also organized an AMS special session, a small mathematics workshop in Japan, and an online conference with attendees from 40 countries.
